case_name: Charandas Haridas and Chinubhai Haridas v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 108 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 108 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated February 16, 1955 in Income-tax Reference No. 35/x of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 16, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 35/x of 1954.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J. on March 15, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: 1960. March 15. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is an appeal with the Hid special leave of this

facts.text: Appellants are Charandas Haridas and Chinubhai Haridas, two assessees with identical cases.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are two assessees, Charandas Haridas and Chinubhai Haridas, whose cases are identical, and, in fact, there was a companysolidated reference

facts.text: Consolidated reference by Income-tax Appellate Tribunal answered by Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: whose cases are identical, and, in fact, there was a companysolidated reference by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, which was answered by the High Court

facts.text: Respondents are Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay North, Kutch and Saurashtra and Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi, Ajmer, Rajasthan and Madhya Bharat.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents are respectively the Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay North, Kutch and Saurashtra and the Commissioner of Income-tax, Delhi, Ajmer, Rajasthan

facts.text: Charandas Haridas represented HUF consisting of wife, three sons and himself.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants represented two units of Hindu undivided families. Charandas Haridas represented his wife, three sons and himself

facts.text: Charandas Haridas was Karta of HUF with wife Shantaben, sons Rameshchandra, Anilkumar, Gautamkumar.

anchor.surface_text: We the undersigned Sheth Charandas Haridas by himself and as the guardian of minors Rameshchandra Charandas, Anilkumar Charandas and Gautamkumar Charandas and Shantaben

facts.text: Charandas Haridas was partner in six managing agency firms in six Mills.

anchor.surface_text: He was a partner in six managing agency firms in six Mills. In previous years, the income received by him as partner in these managing agencies

facts.text: Income from managing agencies previously assessed as HUF income.

anchor.surface_text: In previous years, the income received by him as partner in these managing agencies was being assessed as the income of the Hindu undivided family.

facts.text: Oral partial partition agreement on December 31, 1945 by Charandas Haridas for himself, three minor sons and wife Shantaben.

anchor.surface_text: On December 31, 1945, Charandas Haridas acting for his three minor sons and himself and Shantaben, his wife, entered into an oral agreement for a partial partition.

facts.text: Partial partition gave one pie share to daughter Pratima in managing commission from Vijaya Mills Co. Ltd. and Gopal Mills Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: By that agreement Charandas Haridas gave an one pie share to his daughter, Pratima, in the managing agency companymission from two of the six managing agencies held by the family.

facts.text: Balance of shares divided into five equal shares between Charandas, wife and sons, effective January 1, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The balance together with the shares in the other managing agencies was divided into five equal shares between Charandas Haridas, his wife and sons. This agreement was to companye into effect

facts.text: Memorandum of partial partition executed on September 11, 1946 reciting oral agreement.

anchor.surface_text: On September 11, 1946, Charandas Haridas acting for himself and his minor sons, and Shantaben executed a memorandum of partial partition in which the above facts were-recited

facts.text: For assessment years 1947-48 and 1948-49, Charandas claimed income as separate, but ITO assessed as HUF.

anchor.surface_text: In the assessment years 1947-48 and 1948-49, Charandas Haridas claimed that the income should numberlonger be treated as the income of the Hindu undivided family but as the separate

facts.text: Appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner unsuccessful.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer declined to treat the income as any but of the Hindu undivided family, and assessed the income as before. An appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held division was of income only, not assets; document a farce.

facts.text: Tribunal declined to state case under s.66(1), High Court ordered under s.66(2).

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal having declined to state a ease under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income- tax Act, Charandas Haridas moved the Bombay High Court, and obtained an order under s. 66 2

facts.text: Question referred: Whether materials justify Tribunal finding that income was HUF income.

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered question in affirmative, held partition ineffective for assets.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave after High Court refused.

anchor.surface_text: Leave to appeal to this Court was refused by the High Court, but Charandas Haridas applied to this Court and obtained special leave, and the present appeal was filed.

anchor.surface_text: The sole question is whether the source was effectively divided for purposes of the Income-tax law, so that the assessment could not be made upon a Hindu undivided family. anchor.surface_text: Hindu law does not further require that the property must in every case be partitioned by metes and bounds, if separate enjoyment can otherwise be secured according to the shares of the members. anchor.surface_text: In the face of the finding that this was a genuine document and not a sham, and that it effectually divided the income and in the circumstances, the assets, the question answers itself in the negative, that is to say, that there were no materials to justify the finding that the income in the share of the commission agency of the Mills was the income of the Hindu undivided family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Genuine partial partition document effectually divided income and assets under Hindu law, disrupting HUF status for income-tax assessment; Tribunal lacked materials for contrary finding

holdings.text: the source was effectively divided for purposes of the Income-tax law, so that the assessment could not be made upon a Hindu undivided family

anchor.surface_text: The sole question is whether the source was effectively divided for purposes of the Income-tax law, so that the assessment could not be made upon a Hindu undivided family. The law was stated by Mayne, and approved by the Privy Council in Pichappa v. Chokalingam in the following words Where a managing member of a joint family enters into a partnership with a stranger the other members of the family do

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partial partition under Hindu law changed family status despite unchanged partnership position; IT law follows Hindu law, not Partnership Act, assessing separated members separately

holdings.text: partial partition binding upon the family disrupting HUF for managing agency commission income assessment
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishing partnership law (ignores HUF), Hindu law (allows partial partition), and IT law (assesses per Hindu law status post-partition); no HUF unit remains for divided assets

holdings.text: Hindu law does not further require that the property must in every case be partitioned by metes and bounds, if separate enjoyment can otherwise be secured according to the shares of the members

anchor.surface_text: Hindu law does not further require that the property must in every case be partitioned by metes and bounds, if separate enjoyment can otherwise be secured according to the shares of the members. For an asset of this kind, there was no other mode of partition open to the parties if they wished to retain the property and yet hold it not jointly but in severally, and the law does not contemplate that a person should do the impossible.

holdings.reasoning_summary: For intangible assets like managing agency shares, income division secures separate enjoyment, sufficient under Hindu law without physical division or partnership changes

holdings.text: The document was fully effective between the members of the family, and there was factually no Hindu undivided family in respect of these particular assets

anchor.surface_text: There is no suggestion here that this division was a mere pretence nor has the Appellate Tribunal given such a finding. The document was fully effective between the members of the family, and there was factually no Hindu undivided family in respect of these particular assets. The assets at all times stood in the name of Charandas Haridas, and looked at from the point of view of the law of Partnership, the family had no standing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence of pretence or sham; oral and written partial partition genuine and disrupted joint family status for specific assets

holdings.text: the Income-tax law looks not to the provisions of the Partnership Act, but to the provisions of Hindu law

anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax law looks not to the provisions of the Partnership Act, but to the provisions of Hindu law. When once the family has disrupted, the position under the partnership continues as before, but the position under the Hindu law changes. There is then no Hindu undivided family as a unit of assessment in point of fact, and the income which accrues, cannot be said to be of a Hindu undivided family.

holdings.reasoning_summary: IT assessment of Karta's partnership income follows Hindu law family status, not partnership formalities; post-partition, income belongs to individuals

holdings.text: The appeal will be allowed. The respondents will pay the costs of the two assessees here and below.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal will be allowed. The respondents will pay the costs of the two assessees here and below.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substantive holdings reverse High Court and Tribunal; appeal succeeds on merits

anchor.surface_text: The law was stated by Mayne, and approved by the Privy Council in Pichappa v. Chokalingam in the following words Where a managing member of a joint family enters into a partnership with a stranger the other members of the family do number ipso facto become partners in the business so as to clothe them with all the rights and obligations of a partner as defined by the Indian Contract Act.

precedents.cited_proposition: Managing member of joint family entering partnership with stranger does not make other family members ipso facto partners; family as unit does not become partner.
precedents.cited_holding: Where a managing member of a joint family enters into a partnership with a stranger the other members of the family do number ipso facto become partners in the business so as to clothe them with all the rights and obligations of a partner as defined by the Indian Contract Act. In such a case the family as a unit does number become a partner, but only such of its members as in fact enter into a companytractual relation with the stranger the partnership will be governed by the Act.

precedents.citation: Appovier v. Rama Subba Aiyan 1866 11 M.I.A. 75

anchor.surface_text: Further, the Privy Council in Appovier v. Rama Subba Aiyan 1 observed Nothing can express more definitely a companyversion of the tenancy, and with that companyversion a change of the status of the family quad this property. The produce is numberlonger to be brought to the companymon chest, as representing the income of an undivided property, but the proceeds are to be enjoyed in six distinct equal shares by the members of the family, who are thenceforth to become entitled to those definite shares.

precedents.cited_proposition: Division of produce into shares effects conversion of tenancy and change in family status regarding that property.
precedents.cited_holding: Nothing can express more definitely a companyversion of the tenancy, and with that companyversion a change of the status of the family quad this property. The produce is numberlonger to be brought to the companymon chest, as representing the income of an undivided property, but the proceeds are to be enjoyed in six distinct equal shares by the members of the family, who are thenceforth to become entitled to those definite shares.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal will be allowed. The respondents will pay the companyts of the two assessees here and below.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment reversed; no materials to justify Tribunal's finding that income was of Hindu undivided family
directions: Respondents will pay the costs of the two assessees here and below

anchor.surface_text: The sole question is whether the source was effectively divided for purposes of the Income-tax law, so that the assessment could not be made upon a Hindu undivided family. The law was stated by Mayne, and approved by the Privy Council in Pichappa v. anchor.surface_text: Hindu law does not further require that the property must in every case be partitioned by metes and bounds, if separate enjoyment can otherwise be secured according to the shares of the members. anchor.surface_text: the Income-tax law looks not to the provisions of the Partnership Act, but to the provisions of Hindu law. When once the family has disrupted, the position under the partnership continues as before, but the position under the Hindu law changes. There is then no Hindu undivided family as a unit of assessment in point of fact, and the income which accrues, cannot be said to be of a Hindu undivided family.
The appeal will be allowed. The respondents will pay the companyts of the two assessees here and below.
